results.content: Instructor was very good.  Easy to understand and obviously knew the subject very well.  So I will look for his other courses in the future.  However, I cannot say the same about the outline of the actual course.  Even though the class was great and I learned a lot, it was hard to follow at the end (starting with "Lightning").   As soon as that section started, it was very apparent that that section is outdated, at least a couple of years old.   This should be updated another person pays for this........  Or at least be up front about that, before someone purchases the class.  It’s really too bad to, because up to that point I really enjoyed the training.
results.content_html: Instructor was very good. Easy to understand and obviously knew the subject very well. So I will look for his other courses in the future. However, I cannot say the same about the outline of the actual course. Even though the class was great and I learned a lot, it was hard to follow at the end (starting with "Lightning"). As soon as that section started, it was very apparent that that section is outdated, at least a couple of years old. This should be updated another person pays for this........ Or at least be up front about that, before someone purchases the class. It’s really too bad to, because up to that point I really enjoyed the training.

The instructor should prepare the student before starting the chapter of what is needed or prerequisted.

The labs that the instructor used sometimes were hard to do because the student does not have the preparation steps available. The instructor should prepare the student before starting the chapter of what is needed or prerequisted.

results.content: It was good as a high-level introduction to Salesforce development. The presentation could have used some editing and perhaps more rehearsal.
results.content_html: It was good as a high-level introduction to Salesforce development. The presentation could have used some editing and perhaps more rehearsal.

results.content: I enrolled just to brush up my Salesforce know-how. I feel the course covers the basics well. However, I would've loved if there were dedicated lectures on Process Builder and Flow. Just 2 more lectures would've make a bit more of a  sweeter deal. I strongly feel that process builder and Flow are sought after skills today for an admin. Overall, the course is fine for a beginner. The visualforce and intro to classes and triggers was like cherry on top of the cake.
results.content_html: I enrolled just to brush up my Salesforce know-how. I feel the course covers the basics well. However, I would've loved if there were dedicated lectures on Process Builder and Flow. Just 2 more lectures would've make a bit more of a sweeter deal. I strongly feel that process builder and Flow are sought after skills today for an admin. Overall, the course is fine for a beginner. The visualforce and intro to classes and triggers was like cherry on top of the cake.

results.content:
I give the guy speaking in the video 10 points for doing walk throughs for all the things. He clearly knows what he;s talking about and doing. However, he;s not an instructor. No offense to the guy. There's very little to no explanation of what's going on. In lecture 12 or 13 (I forget which), going over the workflows he does an example where we have to mess with a bit of code to get it to work right. Now, if you know code, awesome, you can probably figure out pretty easy what he's doing. But if your'e  a dummy like me, the low res video does not let you see what exactly is going on, and trying to copy what he's doing to get the syntax correct proves quite the task. He doesn't explain it really at all. Sort of frustrating. 

As said, it's better than not having any guidance, but if you're a complete noob like me, probably not the best course to take. If I had paid $200 for it, I'd have wanted my money back. As it was, I only paid $24  with Udemy's promo, so it's all good.
results.content_html:
I give the guy speaking in the video 10 points for doing walk throughs for all the things. He clearly knows what he;s talking about and doing. However, he;s not an instructor. No offense to the guy. There's very little to no explanation of what's going on. In lecture 12 or 13 (I forget which), going over the workflows he does an example where we have to mess with a bit of code to get it to work right. Now, if you know code, awesome, you can probably figure out pretty easy what he's doing. But if your'e a dummy like me, the low res video does not let you see what exactly is going on, and trying to copy what he's doing to get the syntax correct proves quite the task. He doesn't explain it really at all. Sort of frustrating.

As said, it's better than not having any guidance, but if you're a complete noob like me, probably not the best course to take. If I had paid $200 for it, I'd have wanted my money back. As it was, I only paid $24 with Udemy's promo, so it's all good.
